newsitem.title: CYPRUS: CP.INTELLIGENCE LOWERS RATINGS OF SKOREAN BANKS.
newsitem.headline: CP.INTELLIGENCE LOWERS RATINGS OF SKOREAN BANKS.

text.p: Cyprus-based Capital Intelligence on Tuesday lowered the ratings of five South Korean banks with high exposures to the troubled Kia Group.

The specialist bank rating agency lowered long-term ratings of Cho Hung Bank, Hanil Bank and Korea Exchange Bank to BBB+, while maintaining short-term outlooks of A-1 and negative outlooks until further notice.

Capital Intelligence said in a news release it was also reducing long term ratings of Korea First Bank and Seoulbank to BB. The short term rating for Korea First Bank has been lowered to A-3 from A-2.
A negative outlook is appended to these ratings until further notice, Capital Intelligence said, adding that it has also assigned a negative outlook to Commercial Bank of Korea.

"The downgrades are a result of the bank's high exposures to Kia as well as their weakening financial conditions due to lost interest income and probable large provisioning requirements on other substantial doubtful debts," said Capital Intelligence.

Capital Intelligence said it expected banks to tighten their loan policies further, thereby increasing the potential for further near-failures which would probably then have to be supported by the banks.
"Hence the string of corporate near-failures is expected to continue and the banks' financial strength is likely to weaken further," Capital Intelligence said.
It also lowered the ratings for Korea Development Bank, from AA long term and A-1+ short term to A+ and A-1, whilst maintaining a negative outlook.
As wholly owned by the governemnt, the bank's risk profile reflects Koreas state of financial affairs, Capital Intelligence said.

"In this regard CI believes that the government's finances are presently being undermined by the potential costs arising from the restructuring of the country's finance and corporate sectors," Capital Intelligence said.
